This is a test task to validate usage metrics collection. Keep implementation simple.

3. Required commands available:

4. Manual hook test works:
   - echo '{"agent_id":"preflight-test","agent_type":"planner","session_id":"test"}' | TASK="Preflight test" .claude/hooks/metrics-start.sh
   - cat .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl | tail -1 | jq .
5. Verify hook matcher pattern includes workflow agents:
   - Should match: analyst|planner|implementer|reviewer

If any pre-flight check fails, STOP and report the issue before proceeding.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA (after completion):
1. File created: utils/greeting.js with the greeting function
2. Metrics file exists: .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl

4. Token data: Each stage_end event has non-zero input_tokens and output_tokens
5. Cost calculated: Each stage_end event has cost_usd field with numeric value > 0
6. Model captured: Each stage_end event has model field (e.g., "claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929")
7. BD comments: Subtask beads issues have metrics comments posted with stage summaries
8. Duration captured: Each stage_end has duration_seconds > 0

- jq 'select(.event=="stage_end") | {stage, tokens, cost_usd, model, duration_seconds}' .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl
- jq -s 'map(select(.event=="stage_end")) | length' .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl  # Should be >= 3 (planner, implementer, reviewer)
- jq -s 'map(select(.event=="stage_end").cost_usd) | add' .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl  # Total cost

All 8 criteria met + validation commands return expected data = SUCCESS

- Catch configuration issues early (missing hooks, wrong settings, missing commands)
- Test hooks manually to ensure they work in isolation
- Validate results with specific jq queries

Phase 1 implemented the full persistence pipeline (JSONL + beads comments) with mock/null token values. Phase 2 is a drop-in replacement - wire up real token data without changing the persistence logic.

- Wire up Claude Code monitoring API (https://code.claude.com/docs/en/monitoring-usage)

  - tokens.output
  - tokens.cache_read
  - tokens.cache_creation
  - cost_usd

- Update hook scripts to read OTLP metrics
- Verify persistence pipeline still works (should be transparent)

**Out of scope:**
- Dashboard/visualization (Phase 3)
- Fast-track task tracking (future)
- Concurrent subagent support (future)

- Real token counts appear in workflow-metrics.jsonl
- Real costs calculated and stored
- Model names captured correctly

- Phase 1 implementation: .claude-l0a (closed)

## Branch
`feature/claude-l0a-usage-metrics-phase1` (already exists and is current)

## Overview
This is a workflow validation test, not a feature build. The greeting utility already exists and all tests pass. The implementer's job is to verify the existing code meets requirements and ensure their stage completion generates metrics events for validation. No new code needs to be written.

## Current State (Verified by Analyst)
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.js` - Working implementation with `generateGreeting(name)` function
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.test.js` - 5 passing test cases covering all edge cases
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/.claude/hooks/metrics-start.sh` - Stage start event capture (Phase 1 complete)
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/.claude/hooks/metrics-end.sh` - Stage end event capture with tokens/cost (Phase 2 complete)
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl` - Metrics storage (active, contains prior test runs)

## What the Implementer Should Do

### 1. Verify Existing Implementation
- [ ] Run `node /Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.test.js` to confirm all 5 tests pass
- [ ] Review `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.js` to confirm it meets the simple requirements:
  - Returns "Hello, [name]!" for valid names
  - Returns "Hello, Guest!" for null/empty/undefined
- [ ] Verify implementation is simple and correct (no changes needed)

### 2. Complete Stage to Generate Metrics
- [ ] Close implementer subtask `.claude-790.3` to trigger metrics-end.sh hook
- [ ] The hook will automatically:
  - Write stage_end event to workflow-metrics.jsonl
  - Post Stage Metrics comment to `.claude-790.3`
  - Include token usage, cost, duration from this session

### 3. No Code Changes Required
The analyst explicitly noted: "No new code needs to be written - greeting utility already exists." The implementer should NOT modify any code unless they find a genuine bug (none expected).

## Files to Verify (Not Change)
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.js` - Utility function (already correct)
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.test.js` - Test suite (already passing)

## Watch Out For

### Don't Overthink This
This task is intentionally simple. The real work happened in `.claude-l0a` (Phase 1 metrics) and `.claude-6t5` (Phase 2 tokens). This task exercises the infrastructure, not builds new features.

### The $TASK Environment Variable
The hooks depend on `$TASK` being set by master. If you see "unknown-task" in metrics, that's a master-level issue, not an implementer concern. The analyst flagged this as a known risk.

### Metrics are Automatic
You don't need to manually trigger metrics collection. The SubagentStop hook fires automatically when you close your subtask. Just close normally and the metrics will flow.

## Testing Approach
No unit tests needed - tests already exist and pass. Validation is:
1. Run existing tests to confirm they pass (they will)
2. Close implementer subtask to generate stage_end metrics event
3. Reviewer will verify metrics were recorded correctly

## Edge Cases (Already Handled)
The analyst confirmed these are all already implemented:
- Name is null → Returns "Hello, Guest!" ✓
- Name is empty string → Returns "Hello, Guest!" ✓  
- Name is undefined → Returns "Hello, Guest!" ✓
- Name is "Alice" → Returns "Hello, Alice!" ✓

## Documentation to Update
None. The analyst's spec explicitly states "No documentation updates needed."

## Artifacts to Update
None. The analyst's spec explicitly states "None required."

## Lessons from Past Work

### From .claude-l0a (Phase 1 Metrics)
- Hook scripts use `set +e` and `|| true` to never break workflow - this pattern is already applied in metrics-start.sh and metrics-end.sh
- jq with `--arg` prevents injection - already used correctly in both hooks
- Exit 0 always pattern - already implemented

### From .claude-6t5 (Phase 2 Tokens)
- grep + jq pipeline for JSONL parsing is efficient - already in metrics-end.sh lines 79-89
- awk for floating-point cost calculation - already in metrics-end.sh lines 115-125
- Transcript parsing is defensive with fallbacks - already implemented

### From .claude-9nr (Inter-Stage Data Passing)
- bd comments are primary data transport - this plan is posted as bd comment per that pattern
- When tool changes happen, verify agent has access - the implementer has Bash tool for running tests

## What Success Looks Like
1. Tests pass when you run them (proving code works)
2. You close your subtask without blocking
3. Metrics-end.sh writes a stage_end event to workflow-metrics.jsonl with your agent_id, tokens, cost, and duration
4. You receive a Stage Metrics comment on your subtask showing the data
5. Reviewer verifies the metrics infrastructure worked end-to-end

## Key Insight
This task is validating infrastructure, not building features. The greeting utility is a trivial excuse to exercise the full workflow (analyst → planner → implementer → reviewer). Each stage generates metrics. That's the real deliverable - proving the hooks work across all stages.

## Review Notes

### Implementation Quality: PASS
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.js` - Clean, correct implementation
- `/Users/tomas/.claude/utils/greeting.test.js` - All 5 tests pass, good edge case coverage

- Stage start/end events written to `workflow-metrics.jsonl`
- All 4 stages recorded (analyst, planner, implementer, reviewer)
- Token data extracted from transcripts (real values, not nulls)

- Stage names captured correctly

**Not working:**
- `$TASK` environment variable = "unknown-task" instead of subtask ID

### Root Cause
The `$TASK` environment variable is not being set by master when spawning subagents. The hooks check `[[ "$task_raw" =~ \. ]]` before posting bd comments, and "unknown-task" fails this check (correctly - avoids posting garbage).

**This is a master orchestration issue, not a hooks bug.** The analyst spec explicitly flagged this risk.

### Minor issues (not fixed)
- `workflow-metrics.jsonl:1-3` - Early test events have empty `stage` field from prior test runs before hooks were updated
- `workflow-metrics.jsonl` - All events show "unknown-task" - expected given the above

title: Verify Ruby version detection mechanism in remote sandbox
description:
The current understanding of Ruby version detection may be incomplete:

**Current CI/CD workflow:**
- Builds ONE image per tag push (e.g., landovsky/claude-sandbox:0.1.1)
- Uses Dockerfile with ARG RUBY_VERSION=3.4.7
- Tags as both versioned (0.1.1) and latest

**ruby-versions.yaml defines:**
- Multiple Ruby versions: 3.2.6, 3.3.6, 3.4.7
- Launcher should select appropriate image based on .ruby-version

**Questions to verify:**
1. Does the build process actually build multiple images (one per Ruby version)?
   - Check bin/claude-sandbox build command implementation
   - Does CI/CD need to build ruby-3.2, ruby-3.3, ruby-3.4 tags?

2. If images ARE built per Ruby version, are they pushed with proper tags?
   - Should be: landovsky/claude-sandbox:ruby-3.2, :ruby-3.3, :ruby-3.4
   - Current workflow only pushes :0.1.1 and :latest

3. If NOT building per version, how does detection work?
   - Are Docker labels used after all?
   - Is there metadata inspection?
   - Does it assume latest = default version?

4. Test the actual behavior:
   - Create a test repo with .ruby-version = 3.2
   - Run bin/claude-sandbox remote and observe what image is selected
   - Verify the Ruby version inside the container

**Acceptance criteria:**
- Document the actual mechanism with evidence
- If multi-version images aren't being built, identify the gap
- Propose fix if needed (update CI/CD workflow or detection logic)
notes:
## VERIFIED: CI/CD workflow is missing multi-version builds

**Local behavior (CORRECT):**
- bin/claude-sandbox build: Creates ruby-3.2, ruby-3.3, ruby-3.4, latest
- bin/claude-sandbox push: Pushes all Ruby version tags

**CI/CD workflow (BROKEN):**
- Only builds ONE image
- Tags: 0.1.1, latest
- Missing: ruby-3.2, ruby-3.3, ruby-3.4 tags

**Impact:**
- Remote sandbox can't select Ruby version-specific images
- Launcher will fail when .ruby-version != default (3.4)
- Only projects with Ruby 3.4 will work

**Fix needed:**
Update .github/workflows/docker-build-push.yml to:
1. Parse ruby-versions.yaml
2. Build multiple images (one per Ruby version)
3. Push all tags: ruby-3.2, ruby-3.3, ruby-3.4, latest, AND semantic version

**Reference:**
- bin/claude-sandbox:419-437 (build logic)
- bin/claude-sandbox:467-479 (push logic)

title: Investigate architectural options for invoking workflow from Github task
description:
Investigate architectural options for invoking the Claude Code execution workflow from GitHub's infrastructure (GitHub Issues/Actions).

CURRENT ARCHITECTURE:
- Workflow: Human → CLI → Docker/K8s → entrypoint.sh → claude execution
- Invocation: claude-sandbox local/remote "task description"
- Service detection: Analyzes Gemfile/package.json for postgres/redis/etc
- Task tracking: .beads/issues.jsonl (beads system)

ARCHITECTURAL OPTIONS:

Option 1: GitHub Actions Trigger
- Use workflow_dispatch or issues event to trigger execution
- Pros: Native integration, built-in logging, GitHub secrets access
- Cons: 6-hour runtime limits, runner capacity constraints
- Approach: Trigger on issue label or workflow_dispatch input

Option 2: GitHub Issues + Webhook
- Webhook listener watches for issue labels/comments
- Pros: Unlimited runtime, own infrastructure control, comment results back
- Cons: Requires webhook endpoint, custom auth/authorization
- Approach: Issue created → Webhook → claude-sandbox remote → Comment results

Option 3: GitHub App with Bot Account
- Full GitHub App monitoring issues/PRs
- Pros: Rich interactions (comments, labels, reviews), fine-grained permissions
- Cons: High development overhead, app registration/hosting required
- Approach: Probot framework → Parse issue/PR → Execute → Update GitHub

Option 4: Beads-GitHub Sync
- Two-way sync between .beads/issues.jsonl and GitHub Issues
- Pros: Leverages existing workflow, GitHub as UI, offline capable
- Cons: Sync complexity, conflict resolution, field mapping
- Approach: bd create ↔ GitHub Issue with bidirectional updates

RECOMMENDED PATH:
1. Prototype Option 1 (GitHub Actions) - fastest validation
2. Design Option 4 (Beads-GitHub sync) - best fit for existing workflow
3. Evaluate Option 2 (Webhook) if more control needed
4. Consider Option 3 only for full product

KEY QUESTIONS:
- Is GitHub Issues source of truth or just trigger?
- Post results back to GitHub (comments/labels)?
- Authentication model (tokens, service accounts)?
- Multi-repo support needed?
- PR-based workflows or issues only?

title: Collect and persist usage data (per task, per workflow stage)
description:
## Problem

Complete blindness to workflow costs - can only see aggregate usage in Claude app UI, no visibility into:
- Per-task token consumption
- Per-stage breakdown (analyst vs planner vs implementer vs reviewer)
- Workflow overhead (can't benchmark workflow vs direct implementation)

**Pain level**: 9-10/10 for data collection & understanding

## Use Cases

1. **Benchmarking**: Compare same task with/without workflow → decide if overhead is worth it (7/10 pain)
2. **Token leak detection**: Spot anomalies (e.g., task used 5x normal tokens) → investigate bugs (10/10 need for data collection)
3. **Understanding distribution**: Which stages cost most? → inform optimization decisions (9/10 pain)

## Scope: Phase 1 Only

**In scope**:
- JSONL metrics collection (`.claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl`)
- Per-stage metrics stored in beads comments
- Basic queryability via jq or bd commands
- Works in remote execution (git-persisted)

**Out of scope** (defer to future):
- Automated analysis/dashboards
- ccusage integration
- Real-time alerts

## Value Assessment

- **Value**: HIGH - addresses critical blindness, enables benchmarking & optimization
- **Effort**: SMALL - Phase 1 only (8-16 hours estimated, AI-assisted)
- **Risk**: LOW-MEDIUM - main concern is actionability, mitigated by clear use cases
- **ROI**: Quick Win (high value, small effort)

## Technical Approach

Per evaluation doc (`artifacts/workflow-design/docs/ccusage-integration-evaluation.md`):
- Token API available: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/monitoring-usage
- JSONL format for metrics: timestamp, workflow_id, task_id, stage, tokens, cost, duration
- Store metrics in beads comments for human readability + git persistence
- Simple queries: `jq 'select(.task_id=="beads-123")' .claude/workflow-metrics.jsonl`

## Validation Summary

✅ Real high-pain problem (9-10/10)
✅ Concrete actionable use cases
✅ Right-sized scope (Phase 1 only)
✅ Technical feasibility confirmed
✅ Foundation exists (evaluation doc)

## Next Steps

When ready to implement:
1. Read evaluation doc for architecture details
2. Implement JSONL collection hooks
3. Add beads comment integration
4. Test with one workflow
5. Validate data is actionable (set calendar reminder to review)

## Context

- Evaluation: `artifacts/workflow-design/docs/ccusage-integration-evaluation.md`
- Scratch file: `artifacts/ideas/scratch/collect-persist-usage-data.md`
- This is a hobby project - optimize for understanding, not financial ROI

title: Plan implementation
notes:
# PostGIS Support - Implementation Plan

## Overview

This plan breaks down the implementation of PostGIS support into discrete, testable steps. Based on the analysis in `postgis-support-spec.md`, we'll implement changes to K8s templates and entrypoint script.

## Implementation Strategy

**Approach**: Use PostGIS image everywhere (backward compatible, simpler)

### Why This Approach?
1. PostGIS is a PostgreSQL extension - 100% backward compatible
2. Docker Compose already uses this approach successfully
3. No conditional logic needed in K8s templates
4. Projects without PostGIS work fine with PostGIS image
5. Simpler to maintain and test

## Step-by-Step Implementation

### Step 1: Update K8s Job Template

**File**: `claude-sandbox/k8s/job-template.yaml`

**Changes**:

1. **Update Postgres sidecar image** (line 96):
   ```yaml
   # Before:
   image: postgres:16-alpine

   # After:
   image: postgis/postgis:16-3.4-alpine
   ```

2. **Update DATABASE_URL scheme** (line 67):
   ```yaml
   # Before:
   value: "postgres://claude:claude@localhost:5432/${DATABASE_NAME:-sandbox_development}"

   # After:
   value: "postgis://claude:claude@localhost:5432/${DATABASE_NAME:-sandbox_development}"
   ```

**Verification**:
- [ ] Image name changed to postgis/postgis
- [ ] Version matches docker-compose.yml (16-3.4-alpine)
- [ ] DATABASE_URL uses postgis:// scheme
- [ ] Variable interpolation preserved: ${DATABASE_NAME:-sandbox_development}

### Step 2: Add Database Readiness Check

**File**: `claude-sandbox/entrypoint.sh`

**Location**: Before Rails database operations (before line 216)

**Implementation**:

```bash
# Wait for database to be ready if Rails project with database
if [ "$HAS_RAILS" = true ]; then
  section "Database Setup"

  # Check if DATABASE_URL is set (indicates we need database)
  if [ -n "$DATABASE_URL" ]; then
    action "Waiting for database to be ready..."

    # Extract connection details from DATABASE_URL
    # Supports both postgres:// and postgis:// schemes
    DB_HOST=$(echo "$DATABASE_URL" | sed -E 's|^[^:]+://[^@]+@([^:]+):.*|\1|')
    DB_PORT=$(echo "$DATABASE_URL" | sed -E 's|^[^:]+://[^@]+@[^:]+:([0-9]+)/.*|\1|')
    DB_USER=$(echo "$DATABASE_URL" | sed -E 's|^[^:]+://([^:]+):.*|\1|')

    # Wait up to 30 seconds for database
    for i in $(seq 1 30); do
      if pg_isready -h "$DB_HOST" -p "$DB_PORT" -U "$DB_USER" > /dev/null 2>&1; then
        success "Database is ready"
        break
      fi
      if [ $i -eq 30 ]; then
        error "Database failed to become ready after 30 seconds"
        exit 1
      fi
      sleep 1
    done
  fi

  action "Preparing Rails database..."
  bundle exec rails db:prepare || bundle exec rails db:setup
  success "Database ready"
  separator
fi
```

**Key Points**:
- Uses `pg_isready` tool (already available in PostgreSQL)
- Extracts host/port/user from DATABASE_URL (works with both schemes)
- 30 second timeout with proper error handling
- Only runs if Rails project detected and DATABASE_URL set
- Uses `$(seq 1 30)` instead of bash-specific `{1..30}` for POSIX compatibility

**Verification**:
- [ ] Readiness check added before db:prepare
- [ ] Extracts connection details correctly
- [ ] 30 second timeout implemented
- [ ] Proper error handling on timeout
- [ ] Success message on ready

### Step 3: Add Redis Readiness Check (Optional)

**File**: `claude-sandbox/entrypoint.sh`

**Location**: Before Redis operations (if any exist in the future)

**Implementation**:

```bash
# Wait for Redis to be ready if REDIS_URL is set
if [ -n "$REDIS_URL" ]; then
  action "Waiting for Redis to be ready..."

  # Extract host and port from REDIS_URL
  REDIS_HOST=$(echo "$REDIS_URL" | sed -E 's|^redis://([^:]+):.*|\1|')
  REDIS_PORT=$(echo "$REDIS_URL" | sed -E 's|^redis://[^:]+:([0-9]+).*|\1|')

  # Wait up to 30 seconds for Redis
  for i in $(seq 1 30); do
    if redis-cli -h "$REDIS_HOST" -p "$REDIS_PORT" ping > /dev/null 2>&1; then
      success "Redis is ready"
      break
    fi
    if [ $i -eq 30 ]; then
      error "Redis failed to become ready after 30 seconds"
      exit 1
    fi
    sleep 1
  done
fi
```

**Note**: This is preparatory work for future Redis-dependent operations. Currently Rails doesn't require Redis to be ready for db:prepare.

**Verification**:
- [ ] Redis check added (conditional on REDIS_URL)
- [ ] Connection details extracted correctly
- [ ] 30 second timeout implemented
- [ ] Proper error handling

### Step 4: Add Database Adapter Detection (Informational)

**File**: `claude-sandbox/entrypoint.sh`

**Location**: After Rails detection (after line 151)

**Implementation**:

```bash
# Detect database adapter if Rails project
DB_ADAPTER=""
if [ "$HAS_RAILS" = true ] && [ -f "config/database.yml" ]; then
  if grep -qE '^\s*adapter:\s*postgis' config/database.yml; then
    DB_ADAPTER="postgis"
    info "Database adapter: PostGIS"
  elif grep -qE '^\s*adapter:\s*(postgresql|postgres)' config/database.yml; then
    DB_ADAPTER="postgresql"
    info "Database adapter: PostgreSQL"
  elif grep -qE '^\s*adapter:\s*mysql2?' config/database.yml; then
    DB_ADAPTER="mysql"
    info "Database adapter: MySQL"
  fi
fi
```

**Purpose**:
- Informational logging only
- Helps debugging database issues
- No conditional behavior based on adapter

**Verification**:
- [ ] Detection added after Rails detection
- [ ] Logs adapter type if found
- [ ] Handles postgis, postgresql, mysql adapters
- [ ] Doesn't break if database.yml missing

### Step 5: Update Documentation

**Files**:
- `claude-sandbox/README.md`
- `claude-sandbox/k8s/TESTING.md`

**Changes**:

1. **README.md** - Update "Pending" section:
   ```markdown
   > **Working:**
   > - ✅ Basic job execution
   > - ✅ SOPS encrypted secrets
   > - ✅ .env.claude plaintext config
   > - ✅ REPO_URL auto-detection
   > - ✅ Parallel deployments
   > - ✅ PostGIS support (backward compatible)
   > - ✅ Database readiness checks
   > - ✅ Redis readiness checks
   >
   > **Pending:**
   > - ⏳ Test with Redis-dependent operations
   > - ⏳ Full production testing
   ```

2. **TESTING.md** - Add PostGIS test case:
   ```markdown
   ### PostGIS Projects
   - [ ] Test with project using adapter: postgis
   - [ ] Test with project using adapter: postgresql
   - [ ] Verify PostGIS extensions available
   - [ ] Verify non-PostGIS projects still work
   ```

## Testing Plan

### Unit Tests (Manual Verification)

1. **URL Parsing Test**:
   ```bash

   export DATABASE_URL="postgis://user:pass@dbhost:5432/mydb"
   DB_HOST=$(echo "$DATABASE_URL" | sed -E 's|^[^:]+://[^@]+@([^:]+):.*|\1|')
   echo "$DB_HOST"  # Should output: dbhost
   ```

2. **Adapter Detection Test**:
   ```bash
   # Create test database.yml with different adapters
   # Verify grep patterns match correctly
   ```

### Integration Tests

1. **Local Docker Compose**:
   - Already using PostGIS ✅
   - Test with hriste project (postgis adapter)
   - Test with non-PostGIS Rails project

2. **K8s Deployment**:
   - Deploy job with PostGIS project
   - Verify logs show "Database is ready"
   - Verify Rails db:prepare succeeds
   - Check database has PostGIS extensions: `SELECT PostGIS_Version();`

3. **Backward Compatibility**:
   - Deploy job with non-PostGIS Rails project
   - Verify everything works as before
   - Verify no PostGIS errors in logs

### Test Projects

1. **With PostGIS**: hriste project (adapter: postgis)
2. **Without PostGIS**: Generic Rails project (adapter: postgresql)
3. **Edge Case**: Rails project with no database.yml

## Rollout Strategy

### Phase 1: K8s Template Update
- Update job-template.yaml
- Test with single project
- Monitor for issues

### Phase 2: Readiness Checks
- Add database readiness check
- Test timeout scenarios
- Test parallel deployments

### Phase 3: Optional Enhancements
- Add Redis readiness check
- Add adapter detection logging
- Update documentation

### Phase 4: Production Validation
- Test with multiple projects
- Monitor performance impact
- Gather feedback

## Risk Assessment

### Low Risk
- ✅ PostGIS is backward compatible with PostgreSQL
- ✅ Docker Compose already uses this approach
- ✅ Readiness checks prevent race conditions

### Medium Risk
- ⚠️ Image size slightly larger (~50MB)
- ⚠️ Regex for URL parsing could fail on edge cases
- **Mitigation**: Test with various DATABASE_URL formats

### High Risk
- None identified

## Rollback Plan

If issues occur:

1. **Revert K8s template**:
   ```bash
   git revert <commit-hash>
   kubectl apply -f claude-sandbox/k8s/job-template.yaml
   ```

2. **Revert entrypoint.sh**:
   ```bash
   git revert <commit-hash>
   # Rebuild and push image
   ```

## Success Metrics

- [ ] Projects with postgis adapter work in K8s
- [ ] Projects with postgresql adapter continue working
- [ ] No database race conditions in logs
- [ ] Database ready within 5 seconds (typical case)
- [ ] Proper error messages if database fails
- [ ] All tests pass

## Dependencies

This implementation addresses:
- ✅ `.claude-l86` - PostGIS support (main feature)
- ✅ `.claude-9ba` - Database readiness check
- ✅ `.claude-sto` - Redis readiness check
- ✅ `.claude-p6j` - Hardcoded database name (uses ${DATABASE_NAME} variable)

## Timeline Estimate

- Step 1 (K8s template): 10 minutes
- Step 2 (DB readiness): 20 minutes
- Step 3 (Redis readiness): 10 minutes
- Step 4 (Adapter detection): 10 minutes
- Step 5 (Documentation): 15 minutes
- Testing: 30 minutes

**Total**: ~1.5 hours

title: Fix K8s job sidecar cleanup issue
description:
Fix K8s job sidecar cleanup issue: sidecars keep running after main container exits, preventing TTL cleanup and wasting resources (1.15 CPU, 2.3Gi per stuck job). Investigate native sidecar support (K8s 1.28+) or implement graceful sidecar shutdown mechanism.

Requirement: Solution must preserve job logs for debugging while releasing tied cluster resources.

title: Improve log management for parallel k8s deployments
description:
When running multiple claude-sandbox jobs in parallel, it's hard to track which logs belong to which job.

Current: bin/claude-sandbox logs shows most recent job only

Improvement: Add labels to job template for better filtering:
- repo: extracted from REPO_URL
- branch: from REPO_BRANCH
- task-type: optional classification

Then update bin/claude-sandbox logs to:
- List all running jobs with labels
- Allow filtering: bin/claude-sandbox logs --repo=hriste --branch=main
- Show job metadata in output

Files to modify:
- bin/claude-sandbox (cmd_remote to add labels, cmd_logs to support filtering)
- k8s/job-template.yaml (add label fields)

Related to parallel deployments support.
